docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Not Just Notebooks: Preparing for a New School Year'' (Personal Health, Aug. 23): The section on children's special health needs is incomplete. The writer and her experts advise that a child's EpiPen or inhaler should be with the child or the teacher rather than in the school office.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'' recalled the strict instructions my pregnant mother received in the 1950's. She was told to hide from her husband all signs that labor was painful, to avoid accidentally making him feel guilty. The writer suggests that we turn the clocks back and return to those dark decades when male comfort reigned supreme even in women-centered endeavors like childbirth.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'' recalled the strict instructions my pregnant mother received in the 1950's. She was told to hide from her husband all signs that labor was painful, to avoid accidentally making him feel guilty.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who are tone deaf -- not your run-of-the-mill bad shower singers but those who truly cannot hear or produce musical tones -- are actually processing the sounds differently in their brains, researchers reported yesterday. The researchers, writing online in Annals of Neurology, said they found the problem in the right side of the brain. The study was led by Isabelle Peretz of the University of Montreal.

headline.main: Do You Hear What I Hear? Well, Maybe Not

docs.snippet: People who are clinically tone deaf are actually processing the sounds differently in their brains, researchers have reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Most American fathers find that attending births is rewarding and that it strengthens their marriage or partnership (''From Delivery Room to Bedroom''). The writer is correct that the experience is traumatic for some and that American medicine exacerbates the problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's hard not to wheedle. Your throat feels as if you've swallowed broken glass, your sinuses have been clogged for a couple of days, you're coughing up green stuff and you're slated to fly in a week.
docs.snippet: Patients often want the drugs, and convincing them otherwise isn't easy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': Perhaps the men ought to just wait down at the gentlemen's club. There, they can maintain their fantasy of women as sexual objects and not concern themselves with the conflicted feelings women often have about sex and their bodies after childbirth. Kate Robinson New York

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re '' From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': My husband and I took the birthing classes at Lenox Hill Hospital 40 years ago.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re '' From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': My husband and I took the birthing classes at Lenox Hill Hospital 40 years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': It is understandable that some men may feel turned off by witnessing birth. But having a partner for support in this sometimes grueling experience is invaluable.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': It is understandable that some men may feel turned off by witnessing birth. But having a partner for support in this sometimes grueling experience is invaluable.

docs.lead_paragraph: William Buchanan knew that his diabetes could lead to foot and ankle ulcers, and that the consequences could be dire. His mother also had diabetes, and he had watched her foot wounds fester to the point that her right leg was amputated. Mr. Buchanan, a 74-year-old resident of Queens, watched his own feet and fretted. ''I didn't know there was anything I could do about it,'' he said.

headline.main: New Priority: Saving Feet Of Diabetics

docs.snippet: Doctors have traditionally viewed amputation as inevitable for many diabetics with foot wounds, but many may be preventable.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': From a young age when women learn the facts of life, they are astonished at how unfair pregnancy and birth are. Women are left to experience the physical process entirely on their own. Sympathetic partners can do little to help (and there are plenty who aren't even sympathetic), the very least of which is being present if the woman requests it.
